perturbation.original_text: 8.3 Disclaimer. THIS IS AN AGREEMENT SOLELY FOR SERVICES, AND THERE SHALL BE NO WARRANTIES, EXPRESS OR IMPLIED, EXCEPT AS STATED HEREIN.
perturbation.changed_text: 8.3 Disclaimer. THIS IS AN AGREEMENT SOLELY FOR SERVICES, AND THERE ARE NO WARRANTIES, EXPRESS OR IMPLIED.
perturbation.explanation: By removing "EXCEPT AS STATED HEREIN", the contract now completely disclaims all warranties, including those that might be legally required by New York law (stated in Section 11.11) for services of this nature. This could include implied warranties of merchantability or fitness for a particular purpose, depending on the specific nature of the services provided under the agreement. This change introduces legal risk by violating consumer protection laws related to warranties.
perturbation.contradicted_law: New York Uniform Commercial Code ยง 2-314 (Implied Warranty of Merchantability), ยง 2-315 (Implied Warranty of Fitness for a Particular Purpose)

perturbation.original_text:
9.4 LIMITATIONS ON LIABILITY. EXCEPT FOR LIABILITY ARISING FROM SECTION 9.3  [Intellectual Property Infringement], IN NO EVENT SHALL EITHER PARTY BE LIABLE TO THE OTHER FOR ANY INDIRECT, SPECIAL, INCIDENTAL, PUNITIVE OR CONSEQUENTIAL DAMAGES, LOSSES, OR EXPENSES INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, LOSS OF USE, LOSS OF PROFITS, OR LOSS OF GOODWILL, EVEN IF THAT PARTY HAS BEEN ADVISED OF THE POSSIBILITY OF SUCH LOSS OR DAMAGE.
                  EXCEPT FOR LIABILITY ARISING FROM SECTION 9.3  [Intellectual Property Infringement], IN NO EVENT
SHALL EITHER PARTY BE LIABLE UNDER THIS AGREEMENT FOR AN AMOUNT GREATER THAN THE
AMOUNT THAT SUCH PARTY HAS EARNED PURSUANT TO THE REVENUE SHARING PROVISIONS OF
SECTION 5.4  [Share of Net Revenue] IN THE TWELVE MONTH PERIOD PRECEDING THE CLAIM.
perturbation.changed_text:
9.4 LIMITATIONS ON LIABILITY. IN NO EVENT SHALL EITHER PARTY BE LIABLE TO THE OTHER FOR ANY INDIRECT, SPECIAL, INCIDENTAL, PUNITIVE OR CONSEQUENTIAL DAMAGES, LOSSES, OR EXPENSES INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, LOSS OF USE, LOSS OF PROFITS, OR LOSS OF GOODWILL, EVEN IF THAT PARTY HAS BEEN ADVISED OF THE POSSIBILITY OF SUCH LOSS OR DAMAGE.
                  IN NO EVENT SHALL EITHER PARTY BE LIABLE UNDER THIS AGREEMENT FOR AN AMOUNT GREATER THAN THE
AMOUNT THAT SUCH PARTY HAS EARNED PURSUANT TO THE REVENUE SHARING PROVISIONS OF
SECTION 5.4  [Share of Net Revenue] IN THE TWELVE MONTH PERIOD PRECEDING THE CLAIM.
perturbation.explanation: By removing "EXCEPT FOR LIABILITY ARISING FROM SECTION 9.3 [Intellectual Property Infringement]", the clause now limits liability even for intellectual property infringements, which could violate laws protecting intellectual property rights. Courts in New York generally disfavor limitations on liability for intentional torts (like willful infringement). By omitting the exception, the clause introduces a legal contradiction.

perturbation.original_text:
11.12 Waiver of Jury Trial. EACH OF THE PARTIES HERETO HEREBY
WAIVES TO THE FULLEST EXTENT PERMITTED BY APPLICABLE LAW ANY RIGHT IT MAY HAVE
TO A TRIAL BY JURY WITH RESPECT TO ANY ACTIONS OR PROCEEDINGS DIRECTLY OR
INDIRECTLY ARISING OUT OF, UNDER OR IN CONNECTION WITH THIS AGREEMENT, OR THE
TRANSACTIONS CONTEMPLATED HEREUNDER.
perturbation.changed_text:
11.12 Waiver of Jury Trial. EACH OF THE PARTIES HERETO HEREBY
WAIVES ANY RIGHT IT MAY HAVE
TO A TRIAL BY JURY WITH RESPECT TO ANY ACTIONS OR PROCEEDINGS DIRECTLY OR
INDIRECTLY ARISING OUT OF, UNDER OR IN CONNECTION WITH THIS AGREEMENT, OR THE
TRANSACTIONS CONTEMPLATED HEREUNDER.
perturbation.explanation: By removing 'TO THE FULLEST EXTENT PERMITTED BY APPLICABLE LAW', the contract implies an absolute waiver of jury trial rights, regardless of legal constraints. New York law may not allow waiving jury trials in all circumstances, especially if the waiver is not knowing, voluntary, and intelligent. The original clause acknowledges these limits. By removing it, the contract attempts to overreach and contradict those legal limitations. This introduces uncertainty as to enforceability and possible legal challenge.
perturbation.contradicted_law: New York Civil Practice Law and Rules (CPLR) regarding jury trial waivers.
